body:
### Problem

When launching nvim with a custom directory (`nvim_appdata=somedir nvim`), I encountered this error from treesitter:
![Screenshot 2024-03-20 130041](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/52043856/0234c1ff-dcbd-426c-89e7-f6b827da2e3b)
To resolve the error, it seems likely that I need to install `nvim-treesitter` and the Lua parser. However, IMO, it shouldn't behave like this.
Please note:
- The directory exists and does not contain any files.
- I only encounter the error when opening a Lua file or the help.

### Steps to reproduce

NVIM_APPNAME=somedir nvim init.lua

### Expected behavior

Present this screen without any error
![Screenshot 2024-03-20 130943](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/52043856/02f07c9a-4637-4a15-9c66-73eefa7b606e)


### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.10.0-dev-d326e04 Build type: RelWithDebInfo LuaJIT 2.1.1710088188 Run "nvim -V1 -v" for more info

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

don't use vim

### Operating system/version

windows 11

### Terminal name/version

Windows Terminal v1.19.10573.0 with wsl

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

build from repo

### Output of `cmake --system-information`

<details>

/* Convert integer to decimal digit literals.  */
#define DEC(n)                   \
  ('0' + (((n) / 10000000)%10)), \
  ('0' + (((n) / 1000000)%10)),  \
  ('0' + (((n) / 100000)%10)),   \
  ('0' + (((n) / 10000)%10)),    \
  ('0' + (((n) / 1000)%10)),     \
  ('0' + (((n) / 100)%10)),      \
  ('0' + (((n) / 10)%10)),       \
  ('0' +  ((n) % 10))

/* Convert integer to hex digit literals.  */
#define HEX(n)             \
  ('0' + ((n)>>28 & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)>>24 & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)>>20 & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)>>16 & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)>>12 & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)>>8  & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)>>4  & 0xF)), \
  ('0' + ((n)     & 0xF))

comment_data.body:
does it happen with `--clean` ?

    NVIM_APPNAME=somedir nvim --clean
You need to make sure Neovim can see the `/usr/local/lib/nvim` directory, where parsers are installed (by default). If you use a custom install, make sure you handle this location as well.

> does it happen with `--clean` ?
> 
> ```
> NVIM_APPNAME=somedir nvim --clean
> ```

Yes, it does

> You need to make sure Neovim can see the `/usr/local/lib/nvim` directory, where parsers are installed (by default). If you use a custom install, make sure you handle this location as well.

Not sure how,??
I don't know how you build and install Nvim; those details are missing from your issue report. Please add them.

> I don't know how you build and install Nvim; those details are missing from your issue report. Please add them.

Done
That doesn't answer my question; these are just the standard variables. We need complete, reproducible steps.

> That doesn't answer my question; these are just the standard variables. We need complete, reproducible steps.

I've just follow the instruction in `README.md` 
- Clone the repo with `gh repo clone neovim/neovim`
- run `sudo make install`

Then please check 
1. Whether `/usr/local/lib/nvim` exists and contains the parsers
2. What :checkhealth says about vim.treesitter 
3. What `:echo &rtp` says

The latter with nvim --clean, first without specifying NVIM_APPNAME.

Well, first, I want to thank you for your help. However, I opted for the nuclear route and rebuilt Neovim, which fixed the issue. I'm not sure what kind of silly mistake I made, and I'm sorry if I caused you to waste your time.
Again, thank you.
I installed nvim from the latest binary release instead of from dnf.

I've been hunting down the same problem for days. There's either something wrong with the bundled parsers available on Fedora 40 (`dnf install neovim`), or I'm missing/misunderstanding an install step.

I can easily reproduce with a Docker container:
```
$ docker run --rm -it fedora:40
[root@f58b51d76c66 /]# dnf install -y neovim
[root@f58b51d76c66 /]# nvim foo.lua

Error detected while processing BufNewFile Autocommands for "*":
Error executing lua callback: /usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:35: Error executing lua: /usr/share/nvim/runtime/fi
letype.lua:36: BufNewFile Autocommands for "*"..FileType Autocommands for "*"..function <SNR>1_LoadFTPlugin[20]..scrip
t /usr/share/nvim/runtime/ftplugin/lua.lua: Vim(runtime):E5113: Error while calling lua chunk: /usr/share/nvim/runtime
/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua:107: no parser for 'lua' language, see :help treesitter-parsers
stack traceback:
        [C]: in function 'error'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua:107: in function 'add'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:111: in function 'new'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:41: in function '_create_parser'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:108: in function 'get_parser'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:416: in function 'start'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/ftplugin/lua.lua:2: in main chunk
        [C]: in function 'nvim_cmd'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:36: in function </usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:35>
        [C]: in function 'nvim_buf_call'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:35: in function </usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:10>
stack traceback:
        [C]: in function 'nvim_cmd'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:36: in function </usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:35>
        [C]: in function 'nvim_buf_call'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:35: in function </usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:10>
stack traceback:
        [C]: in function 'nvim_buf_call'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:35: in function </usr/share/nvim/runtime/filetype.lua:10>
Press ENTER or type command to continue
```

Possibly related package bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2283574

I worked around the problem by installing the plugin myself and explicitly calling `:TSInstallSync lua` (plus `vimdoc`).

>  There's either something wrong with the bundled parsers available on Fedora 40 (dnf install neovim)

Yes, that is very likely. And you **must** install the bundled parsers via nvim-treesitter if you use nvim-treesitter.

> I worked around the problem by installing the plugin myself and explicitly calling `:TSInstallSync lua` (plus `vimdoc`).

The problem was still there after I called `:TSInstallSync lua`. :(

My solution was:
sudo ln -s /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/nvim/ /usr/lib64/nvim

because I noticed that /usr/lib64/nvim is already in my rtp in vim:
echo &rtp

/home/anton/.config/nvim-min,/home/anton/.local/share/nvim-min/site,/home/anton/.local/share/nvim-min/laz
y/lazy.nvim,/usr/share/nvim/runtime,/usr/share/nvim/runtime/pack/dist/opt/matchit,/usr/lib64/nvim,/home/a
nton/.config/nvim-min/after,/home/anton/.local/state/nvim-min/lazy/readme

There is probably a **<ins>bad hacky way</ins>** which completely disables treesitter with `init.lua`, but it works for me and don't requires installing parsers which i don't use:

```
vim.treesitter.start = function() return end
```
Tested with neovim 0.10.0 from pkgsrc.

title: No Parser Found for 'lua' Language in Treesitter
